ratings.comment: This class is taken by lazy economics majors who aren't history majors so the rating are skewed. I liked her a lot and the class was fascinating. Just be prepared to study and not expect her to make beliefs for you. It helps to take PS 106 to have an understanding of political economy and capitalism first. Great professor and class.

Dunlavy's nice and all but sitting through her lectures was borderline unbearable. She's incredibly deadpan and monotone. Lectures are recorded and posted online, and they don't really help you with the papers (mostly outside readings), so it's really tough to force yourself to go. Like everyone else, I found her essay prompts impossibly broad.

I didn't think the lectures were as bad as some people have made out. Still, they certainly weren't great. She's nice enough, but like people have said the essay questions are so incredibly broad it's tough to know exactly what to write about.

She obviously knows the subject well but her lectures were very boring. The class involves three 5-7 page papers with extremely broad requirements and a blue book essay final with the same. As some have said, it's very difficult to figure out what she's looking for and the grading seems somewhat arbitrary. Overall, a decent, but not great class.

Lectures are boring and she posts them online so its hard to motivate yourself to go. The material should be interesting but she somehow made it dull. I did well but the paper grading seemed to be somewhat arbitrary. 3 papers (longest 6-7 pages)and a final so the workload is manageable. Its not a tough class but I would avoid Dunlavy if you can.

4.3 average?? Clearly an intelligent woman but is just not a good teacher. Most of the class is based on her own research and ideas, which is good, but you get the feeling she cares more about her own work than teaching. Lecturing is plodding and deadpan. PowerPoints were recondite. Papers were just frustrating and not challenging in a good way.

Run Away! Fast! I'm a history major and this is by far the most boring class I have ever taken. The 3 essays are ridiculously vague and impossible to know what is expected of you. The power lectures feel as though they will never end. She is a nice lady, I just think she is too smart for her own good.

Professor Dunlavy loves business history and it shows with her knowledge and passion of the subject when lecturing. She records her lectures audio and syncs it with the P.P's she posts online, which is very helpful for writing papers. 3,4, and 5 page papers were due and then a 2 essay questions final.
I think the material in this class is rather dry but Dunlavy attempts to make it interesting.

The class is very interesting, but the lectures can be a bit dry. She is very straightforward about what she wants on papers and tests, which is very helpful. Very nice and approachable. Lectures are all recorded and put online, which is amazing for reviewing. Would recommend this class.

Class is for the most part interesting and very straight forward and professor dunlavy was very nice and knew what she was talking about. Lectures are not mandatory, but discussion is, do the readings and you will do fine on the papers.

Three papers. One final exam. This class is pretty easy if you attend class once in awhile & look at her website. This prof is incredibly nice and approachable. She is also very organized & straight-foward about what is expected. Good class.

She's organized, well-spoken and very willing to meet with students. This class is pretty easy if you attend lecture-if not you may encounter some trouble when writing the paper assignments. She's a fair grader-there was only 1 exam (final) and 3 papers. I'd highly recommend 247.

Fantastic! Her lectures are extremely well-planned and she uses Powerpoint.  She doesn't just talk for an hour, each lecture has a topic.  The readings are long but there's only 2 papers and a final.  Overall, a very good professor who makes the History of American Business interesting. Recommended.
